body: For any questions, concerns, or clarification on implementing this issue, please ping @dbczumar
@serena-ruan volunteers to do this task, assign it to her. :)
Thanks @serena-ruan, looking forward to your contribution!

@dbczumar May I ask a few questions to clarify the problem a bit? From the initial issue and description, I feel like that we can directly wrap over mlflow.pyfunc's methods into the utility function to make validation of data schemas work for all flavors, and `predict` just comes for free. The only difference is that _enforce_schema has certain limits on the data type, and prediction results may fall out of that range. So I have this simple draft of outline: Please feel free to correct me if I'm wrong :D

Hi @serena-ruan! Thank you for clarifying.

- I think that exposing an `mlflow.models.validate_schema()` method with the same arguments from your `SchemaUtils.validate_schema` method is a great idea.

- Right now, `mlflow.pyfunc.predict()` already performs schema validation, so `model.predict(data)` will already fail if `data` does not match the model's schema. Accordingly, I don't think we need `predict_and_validate_schema`.

- Finally, it would be nice to make it easier for users to fetch the signature of the model using the URI. For this, I think we can introduce an `mlflow.models.get_model_info()` method that returns a https://mlflow.org/docs/latest/python_api/mlflow.models.html#mlflow.models.model.ModelInfo object corresponding to the model.

Let me know if this helps, and apologies for the slight ambiguity in the issue description.

Hi @dbczumar thanks for the clarification!
1. This sounds good, I'll add the method into mlflow/models/model.py, so that users can directly call mlflow.models.validate_schema().
2. I think `mlflow.pyfunc.predict` only does the input data schema check with `_enforce_schema`, it doesn't validate the output schema of predict. As for the third bullet in the above proposal `Perform a prediction of the provided sample data and ensure that the output schema matches the signature's outputs.` do we want to validate the output schema as well?
3. There's already a method of `get_model_info` https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/master/mlflow/models/model.py#:~:text=def%20get_model_info(self)%3A
When user uses `mlflow.xxx.log_model` it returns `Model.log(xxx)`, which internally calls this `get_model_info` method, so the return value of log_model is exactly the ModelInfo object. I'll check if there're any exceptions for different flavors. And if we want to expose another API that user can directly retrieve ModelInfo from url, then we canadd the API of `get_model_info(model_uri)` as well. We can discuss more in the follow-up PR :)

> Hi @dbczumar thanks for the clarification!
> 
> 1. This sounds good, I'll add the method into mlflow/models/model.py, so that users can directly call mlflow.models.validate_schema().
> 2. I think `mlflow.pyfunc.predict` only does the input data schema check with `_enforce_schema`, it doesn't validate the output schema of predict. As for the third bullet in the above proposal `Perform a prediction of the provided sample data and ensure that the output schema matches the signature's outputs.` do we want to validate the output schema as well?
> 3. There's already a method of `get_model_info` https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/master/mlflow/models/model.py#:~:text=def%20get_model_info(self)%3A
>    When user uses `mlflow.xxx.log_model` it returns `Model.log(xxx)`, which internally calls this `get_model_info` method, so the return value of log_model is exactly the ModelInfo object. I'll check if there're any exceptions for different flavors. And if we want to expose another API that user can directly retrieve ModelInfo from url, then we can add the API of `get_model_info(model_uri)` as well. We can discuss more in the follow-up PR :)

1. Awesome! :)

2. I don't think we want to validate the output schema of predictions produced by the model, since we can trust that the model produces outputs according to its schema. In contrast, we cannot trust that an arbitrary input complies with the model's schema, which is why a separate utility for validating a dataset against a schema is really helpful.

3. `Model.get_model_info()` requires the model to be loaded in the current Python environment. Users may not want to download and restore the model in order to read its signature, e.g. if the model has a lot of dependencies. I think that `mlflow.models.get_model_info()` will be helpful.
